Award.AwardTitle: ASSIST-Academic and Student Support to Imporve STEM Transfer

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
East Los Angeles College (ELAC) is providing the programmatic, academic and student support necessary to increase the annual number of STEM graduates and transfers by 60 students by the end of five years, which is 64% growth over baseline. The project improves articulation at both high school to college and two-year to four-year institution levels; implements faculty advisement and counseling, assigns students to faculty mentors who help design efficient educational plans and STEM pathways; expands research and internship opportunities at university laboratories; and exposes students to professional milieus, broadens their vision of career opportunities, and helps them to develop research skills. In addition, a summer bridge program attracts high school juniors and seniors who have not previously considered STEM careers.

Given its large Hispanic enrollment, advancing STEM education at ELAC helps to increase Latino STEM graduates and transfers. Increased rates of graduation and transfer enable more educationally disadvantaged Latinos to enter the STEM workforce. With this project, the college's infrastructure is redesigned to focus on opportunities in STEM careers, and to smooth transfer pathways to regional universities. Faculty participation in advising, mentoring and sharing of effective pedagogical methods helps transform ELAC into a STEM transfer gateway institution. ELAC disseminates information about the project to similar types of institution, shares best practices, and encourages them to adopt procedures to increase STEM transfers and graduates.

POR.DRECONTENT:
East Los Angeles College serves more Latino students annually than any other community college in the California Community College System (113 colleges).  ELAC received a five year NSF grant in 2011 with a major goal “to increase the number of STEM graduates and/or transfers.” The ASSIST Project (Academic and Student Support to improve STEM Transfers) did see an increase in the number of STEM transfers with more than 840 students transferring during the grant period.  Following is a description of ASSIST’s three major activities and their outcomes.

  1. STEM Summer Research and Internships

 STEM programs support students  in undergraduate research opportunities and industry internships.  A total of 167 students participated in summer research projects and internships (2016-41; 2015-34; 2014-41; 2013-22; 2012-29). During the grant, ELAC was able to expand its internship site offerings to many prestigious organizations including NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory, UC Berkeley, Rocky Mountain Biological Laboratory, University of Southern California (USC) STEM Consortium, U.S. Navy, and the UCLA Wireless Health Institute. In 2016, ELAC began the Biotech Leaders Program. Highlights included two students who presented their research at the Gulf Coast Undergraduate Research Symposium hosted at Rice University on October 22, 2016.

  1. STEM Summer Academy

The STEM Summer Academy is a five-week summer program designed for recent high school graduates who participate in the summer academy before their first semester at ELAC.  The program consists of a mathematics and English review, university field trips, workshops on academic success in college, and science and engineering experiments.  In the Fall, eligible students participate in an accelerated math cohort to become calculus ready in one academic year. More than 90% of students surveyed strongly agreed that doing hands-on activities or projects and/or introductions to the ELAC STEM –related clubs had a lot of impact on them. Having the program on a college campus and working with science faculty made a lot of difference to 75% and 69% of the students, respectively

STEM Counselor

STEM students visit the STEM counselor significantly more often than they visit General Counselors. The STEM counselor received “very good” or “Excellent” ratings ranging from 82% to 87. In contrast, ratings for general counselors on the same questions only ranged from 37% to 54%. The college, partially due to the success of this activity in the ASSIST project, is now in the process of institutionalizing the STEM Counselor position.

Project Outcomes and NSF Merit Review Criteria

The following table presents a quantitative summary of the project objectives, updated as of November 1st, 2016.  The delta value indicates the difference between the target number of students stated in the grant and the actual number of students that met each of the objectives.

Proposed Objective (by 2016)

As of Fall 2016

Delta to 2016

30 of 180 high school students enrolled in summer academy will successfully graduate or transfer as STEM majors

14

-16

50 of 200 STEM students engaged in mentoring programs will successfully graduate or transfer as STEM majors

101

+51

125 of 500 STEM students who meet with a STEM counselor, and create detailed degree plans will graduate or transfer as STEM majors

214

+89

63 of 125 STEM students who participate in research will successfully graduate or transfer as STEM majors

76

+13

80 of 160 STEM students will matriculate directly into B.A./B.S. level STEM programs as a result of robust articulation with universities

214

+134

 

Lessons learned from ELAC’s ASSIST project can be used as best practices for other community colleges who serve underserved STEM Hispanic/Latino and Asian students. Recommendations from important project findings related to student learning include having STEM programs at community colleges hire a dedicated STEM Counselor, implement a STEM Summer Academy and develop and coordinate a network of STEM summer research and internships opportunities. ASSIST experience demonstrated quite clearly the impact these research and internship activities had on significantly improving rates for student retention, and rates of STEM transfers and STEM degrees awarded. Involvement in summer research and internships also considerably improved student career opportunities in STEM fields.

Broader Impacts

ELAC’s involvement in the ASSIST project contributed to the understanding of STEM education, particularly STEM education and research at the community college level. Community college students who declare as STEM majors and who receive institutional support (STEM counseling and a Summer Academy) in addition to participating in summer research and internships, have shown to have greater success in four-year schools compared to transfer students who did not receive ASSIST type support.

The ASSIST project has the potential to contribute to transformative change at ELAC as the STEM education model developed and implemented by the program has become part of the college fabric. For example, the college has its first STEM Dean (Dr. Armando Rivera-Figueroa) and has opened (August, 2016) its new Science and Math building.

Modified by: Armando Rivera-Figueroa

Addendum # 1

Other Conference Presentations / Papers

 

Rueda, M.D., Reynaga, P. and Rivera-Figueroa, A.M. (2013). STEM Mentor Program: Enhancing Students’ STEM Experience and Academic Success.. STEP 2013: Identifying Best Practices. Washington DC

 

Rueda, M.D. and Rivera-Figueroa, A.M. (2013). STEM Mentor Program: Enhancing Students’ STEM Experience and Academic Success.. AHSIE 2013 Best Practices Conference. Jersey City, NJ

 

Rueda, M.D., Reynaga, P. and Rivera-Figueroa, A.M. (2014). Developing a STEM Faculty Mentor Training Program. NSF STEP 2014. Washington DC.

 

Rueda, M.D., Reynaga, P. and Rivera-Figueroa, A.M. (2014). High School STEM Summer Bridge Program to Community College. NSF STEP 2014 Washington DC.

 

Arenas, R. and Rivera-Figueroa, A.M. (2014). Supplemental Instruction (SI) Coaching in Math – Reaching Farther. AHSIE 2014: 6th Annual HSI, Title V Best Practices Conference. La Verne CA

 

Martinez, M. and Rivera-Figueroa, A.M. (2014). East Los Angeles College Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (STEM) Programs. National Institute of Standard and Technology. Gaithersburg, MD.

 

Estrella, V., Gonzalez, C. and Rivera-Figueroa, A.M. (2014) Increasing Competitiveness of First Generation Community College Students Pursuing a STEM Degree. 2014 Hispanic Association of Colleges and Universities Annual Conference. Denver, CO.

 

Ragusa, G. and Rivera-Figueroa, A.M. (2014). Understanding the impact of formal and informal pedagogical support on Hispanic, first generation STEM college students’ success. 2014 Transforming STEM Higher Education, American Association of Colleges & Universities. Atlanta, GA

ELAC received a five year NSF grant in 2011 with a major goal "to increase the number of STEM graduates and/or transfers." The ASSIST Project (Academic and Student Support to improve STEM Transfers) did see an increase in the number of STEM transfers with more than 840 students transferring during the grant period. Following is a description of ASSIST?s three major activities and their outcomes.STEM Summer Research and Internships STEM programs support students in undergraduate research opportunities and industry internships. A total of 167 students participated in summer research projects and internships (2016-41; 2015-34; 2014-41; 2013-22; 2012-29). During the grant, ELAC was able to expand its internship site offerings to many prestigious organizations including NASA?s Jet Propulsion Laboratory, UC Berkeley, Rocky Mountain Biological Laboratory, University of Southern California (USC) STEM Consortium, U.S. Navy, and the UCLA Wireless Health Institute. In 2016, ELAC began the Biotech Leaders Program. Highlights included two students who presented their research at the Gulf Coast Undergraduate Research Symposium hosted at Rice University on October 22, 2016.STEM Summer Academy The STEM Summer Academy is a five-week summer program designed for recent high school graduates who participate in the summer academy before their first semester at ELAC. The program consists of a mathematics and English review, university field trips, workshops on academic success in college, and science and engineering experiments. In the Fall, eligible students participate in an accelerated math cohort to become calculus ready in one academic year. More than 90% of students surveyed strongly agreed that doing hands-on activities or projects and/or introductions to the ELAC STEM –related clubs had a lot of impact on them. The STEM counselor received "very good" or "Excellent" ratings ranging from 82% to 87. In contrast, ratings for general counselors on the same questions only ranged from 37% to 54%. The college, partially due to the success of this activity in the ASSIST project, is now in the process of institutionalizing the STEM Counselor position. Project Outcomes and NSF Merit Review Criteria The following table presents a quantitative summary of the project objectives, updated as of November 1st, 2016. The delta value indicates the difference between the target number of students stated in the grant and the actual number of students that met each of the objectives. Proposed Objective (by 2016) As of Fall 2016 Delta to 2016 30 of 180 high school students enrolled in summer academy will successfully graduate or transfer as STEM majors 14 -16 50 of 200 STEM students engaged in mentoring programs will successfully graduate or transfer as STEM majors 101 +51 125 of 500 STEM students who meet with a STEM counselor, and create detailed degree plans will graduate or transfer as STEM majors 214 +89 63 of 125 STEM students who participate in research will successfully graduate or transfer as STEM majors 76 +13 80 of 160 STEM students will matriculate directly into B.A./B.S. level STEM programs as a result of robust articulation with universities 214 +134 Lessons learned from ELAC?s ASSIST project can be used as best practices for other community colleges who serve underserved STEM Hispanic/Latino and Asian students. Community college students who declare as STEM majors and who receive institutional support (STEM counseling and a Summer Academy) in addition to participating in summer research and internships, have shown to have greater success in four-year schools compared to transfer students who did not receive ASSIST type support. The ASSIST project has the potential to contribute to transformative change at ELAC as the STEM education model developed and implemented by the program has become part of the college fabric.
